author: PA News Agency
title: Mary Earps, Michael Eavis and Justin Welby named in New Year Honours list | Swindon Advertiser
text: England goalkeeper Mary Earps, Glastonbury founder Michael Eavis and Game of Thrones actor Emilia Clarke are among the stars of sport, stage and screen recognised in the New Year Honours list, while the Archbishop of Canterbury leads those rewarded for their work on the King’s coronation. Singer Dame Shirley Bassey, who has sold more than 135 million records, is made Companion of Honour for her services to music, becoming the 64th living member of the order which can only have 65 members at any one time. Dame Shirley, who was born and grew up in Tiger Bay in Cardiff, told the PA news agency: “My heart is full of emotion and I am truly humbled.” Director and producer Sir Ridley Scott, whose works include Gladiator, Alien and Napoleon, is made a Knight Grand Cross, upgrading his previous knighthood, while author Jilly Cooper becomes a dame. She told PA: “I am absolutely and incredibly bowled over. I cannot believe I am a DBE, which in my case also stands for Delighted, Bewildered and Ecstatic.” Sir Justin Welby, the Archbishop of Canterbury, is made a Knight Grand Cross of the Royal Victorian Order (RVO) for his personal service to the Crown during the coronation at Westminster Abbey in May. Awards of the RVO are in the King’s gift and are bestowed independently of Downing Street to people who have served the monarch or the royal family in a personal way. Sir Justin conducted the service for the coronation and had the momentous task of anointing and crowning Charles and Camilla. Other notable names in the list include England cricketer Stuart Broad, who is made a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) following his retirement; singer Leona Lewis, who becomes an Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE); and author Kate Mosse, who is also made a CBE. Elsewhere, Game Of Thrones star Emilia Clarke has been made a Member of the Order of the British Empire (MBE) alongside her mother Jenny as co-founders of SameYou, a brain injury recovery charity they established after she survived two brain haemorrhages. Clarke, who shot to fame playing the Mother of Dragons in the hit HBO series, told the PA news agency the honour was “remarkable” and felt it was “life-enhancing and magical” to see her mother, who has also had surgery to remove a brain aneurysm, also recognised for the work. Other showbiz names honoured include radio disc jockey Tony Blackburn, who is made an OBE, fellow DJ Steve Wright, sports broadcasters Jeff Stelling and Hazel Irvine and Great British Bake Off judge Paul Hollywood, who each are made MBEs. In politics, former chancellor and home secretary Sajid Javid has been knighted, Dame Margaret Beckett, Labour MP for Derby South, has had her damehood upgraded to a Dame Grand Cross, and Siobhain McDonagh, Labour MP for Mitcham and Morden, has been made a Dame Commander. In an unusual move, Liz Truss’s resignation honours were published at the same time as the separate New Year Honours, more than 14 months after the end of her tumultuous 49 days as prime minister, when she was forced out of office after the budget outlined by her chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng sparked an economic crisis. Mr Kwarteng is not on her list, but there are peerages for Matthew Elliott and Jon Moynihan, former chief executive and chairman respectively of Vote Leave, and her deputy chief of staff Ruth Porter, and honours for four MPs, two special advisers, her constituency Conservative Association chairman and author Shirley Conran. Glastonbury Festival founder Sir Michael, listed under his full name Athelstan Joseph Michael Eavis, said he was looking forward to his investiture after being knighted for services to music and charity. In an interview for the official Glastonbury website, Sir Michael said: “I think William might do the ceremony. “He’s made a few mentions of wanting to come to the festival. “So I’ll probably take a couple of tickets in my pocket!” In sport, England captain Millie Bright has been made an OBE, while her fellow Lionesses Earps and Lauren Hemp have been made MBEs for services to football after they finished runners-up to Spain in the women’s World Cup. The honour caps a remarkable month for Earps after she was crowned 2023 BBC Sports Personality of the Year in a public vote. Bright told PA she was “gobsmacked” when she heard about the OBE, adding: “It’s something you never imagined, something that never crossed my mind.” Hemp said: “I’d like to dedicate my MBE to everyone that has supported me in my career so far, and everyone behind the scenes for continuing to push boundaries to get women’s football to where it is today.” In rugby, Sir Bill Beaumont has been made Knight Grand Cross for services to rugby union football and to charity, while former Scotland star and record try-scorer Stuart Hogg is made an MBE. Wetherspoon pub chain boss Tim Martin is knighted amid reports a Government minister pushed for his nomination to reward his Brexit campaigning. Sir Tim, who was knighted for services to hospitality and culture, told PA: “I’d like to think that (the knighthood) is not for my rarely disclosed political views – I hope it is for what it says on the tin.” Novelist Ms Mosse, a co-founder of the Women’s Prize for Fiction, has been made CBE for services to literature, to women and to charity. She told PA: “It does feel that although obviously this is for me, it’s very much an acknowledgement of the importance of the Women’s Prize, and that it matters that women support other women.” Former director of public prosecutions Max Hill, who stepped down in October after five years in the role, is made Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath. Sir Max Hill KC, said: “My time at the Crown Prosecution Service was marked by unprecedented challenges including the pandemic and striving to improve the criminal justice response to rape and domestic violence. “I am very grateful for this honour, which is a testament to the thousands of CPS staff and prosecution advocates who work tirelessly to help victims and to deliver justice.” This year’s list includes a total of 1,227 recipients, 48% of whom are women, while 13.8% come from an ethnic minority background. The oldest recipient is Jill Gladwell, 97, from Stowmarket, who has become an MBE for her voluntary services to the Royal British Legion in Suffolk, while nine-year-old Tony Hudgell has been awarded a British Empire Medal (BEM) for services to the prevention of child abuse. Tony is believed to be the youngest ever recipient of an honour, a record previously held by fundraiser Tobias Weller, who was 11 when he received a BEM two years ago. Ian Russell, father of 14-year-old Molly Russell, who took her own life after viewing harmful material on social media, has become an MBE for services to child safety online. Last September, a coroner ruled schoolgirl Molly, from Harrow, north-west London, died from “an act of self-harm while suffering from depression and the negative effects of online content” in November 2017. Mr Russell has set up the Molly Rose Foundation suicide prevention charity in her memory and has contributed to the establishment of the Online Safety Bill. On what Molly would have made of his MBE, he told PA: “Molly was quite content to get on stage and take part in school plays, but she was a quiet person, she didn’t like the limelight, so I think she would have found this a bit strange. “But because she was such a caring person I think she would have been tremendously proud of being able to help people who may be struggling with their mental health and may be beginning to have thoughts about suicide. “If she thought she could help those people live long and stay strong, she’d be very proud indeed.” Former rugby league players Rob Burrow and Kevin Sinfield have both been made CBEs for services to motor neurone disease (MND) awareness. Burrow won eight Super League titles with Leeds and represented Great Britain and England before he announced he had been diagnosed with MND at the age of 37 in 2019. Inspired by his former Leeds team-mate, Sinfield this month battled through a gruelling schedule of running seven ultramarathons in as many days in seven different cities around Britain and Ireland. His latest fundraising challenge to help people living with MND raised more than £1 million. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said: “The New Year’s Honours List recognises the exceptional achievements of people across the country and those who have shown the highest commitment to selflessness and compassion. “To all honourees, you are the pride of this country and an inspiration to us all.” Comments: Our rules We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. author: Lucas Frau
title: Pizza Hut boycott due to Israel Instagram post. A look at why
text: Pizza Hut may be the latest franchise to face protests due the store's perceived support of Israel during the warfare currently happening in Gaza. Last week, Pizza Hut Israel's Instagram account reposted a photo from the user alex_shults which depicts two soldiers smiling and holding several pizza boxes in their hands. Quads News Network, a Palestinian youth news agency, took screenshots of the photo and posted it to X, formerly, known as Twitter. Boycotts: Why are people boycotting Starbucks? A look inside the scrutiny of the coffee chain Palestinian supporters are calling for consumers to boycott the pizza brand for their latest actions. The hashtag #boycottpizzahut has nearly half a million views on TikTok. On Pizza Hut's official Instagram page, the top comment on their latest post reads "We ordered pizza tonight and it WASN'T from you #freepalestine." Pizza Hut officials have not made a statement regarding their Israel Instagram account or about potential consumer boycotts. Pizza Hut joins the likes of Starbucks that have received backlash due to their stances on the conflict in the Middle East. Palestinian supporters began boycotting Starbucks due to statements made by the company that refused to acknowledge their union's support of Palestine amid the ongoing war between Israel and Hamas. Starbucks CEO, Laxman Narasimhan, released a public statement saying that the protests are stemming from a "misrepresentation on social media of what we stand for." He goes on to say that the coffee chain stands for humanity. Starbucks will release a quarterly report in February which may give light to observe if the boycotts have affected their sales in a significant way.

author: Lluna Bartual
title: La Mancomunitat de l'Horta Sud lanza las primeras jornadas de educación en movilidad sostenible
text: VALÈNCIA. En el contexto actual -con València como Ciudad Verde- la movilidad sostenible se ha convertido en uno de los grandes temas que ocupan la agenda política. Con el aumento de la población y la congestión vehicular, surgen desafíos significativos para la calidad del aire, la seguridad vial y la eficiencia energética en las ciudades. En un entorno mayoritariamente urbano, promover prácticas de movilidad sostenible, como el uso del transporte público, la bicicleta o la movilidad activa, se presenta como una solución integral para abordar estos problemas y promover un entorno urbano más habitable y saludable. Desde la Mancomunitat de l'Horta Sud consideran algo fundamental educar a las nuevas generaciones desde una edad temprana sobre los principios de la movilidad sostenible y la seguridad vial. Al hacerlo, se fomenta la adopción de hábitos de transporte responsables que contribuyen a reducir el impacto ambiental y a mejorar la calidad de vida en las ciudades. Es por ello por lo que han puesto en marcha un proyecto innovador: La formación "Mobilidad Sostenible y Proyectos Europeos". En colaboración con Movea Consulting, empresa adjudicataria para el proyecto, y con el apoyo de la Fundación Mapfre, el objetivo de esta iniciativa es impartir educación vial y promover la movilidad sostenible entre los alumnos de primaria en la región. Desde ayer mismo, 15 de febrero, hasta el mes de mayo, se llevarán a cabo más de 20 sesiones, una en cada municipio participante. Aldaia ha sido el punto de inicio de este proyecto, seguido por otras localidades en fechas posteriores. Alrededor de 50 jóvenes del municipio han participado en esta primera formación en la que se ha impartido contenido centrado en la nueva normativa de patinetes eléctricos. Los cursos se encuentran dentro del proyecto “Serà 2030”, una apuesta firme por los Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible (ODS). A la sesión han acudido el presidente de la Mancomunitat, José Cabanes; el alcalde d'Aldaia, Guillermo Luján, la concejala de Educación, Laura Moruno, y el asesor de movilidad de Movea Consulting, Juan Bueno. La primera de las formaciones ha sido considerada "un éxito". De hecho, Bueno ha asegurado que ha superado todas las expectativas. Este proyecto constará de dos partes de formación, con una duración total de no más de dos horas. En la primera parte, se llevará a cabo una sesión teórica de poco más de media hora, en la que se abordarán conceptos relacionados con la movilidad sostenible, la seguridad vial y cómo estas afectan el entorno urbano en el día a día. La segunda parte será interactiva y práctica, destinada a los alumnos de sexto de primaria. En esta parte, se identificarán y corregirán errores comunes en materia de movilidad, involucrando activamente a los estudiantes en el proceso de aprendizaje. El objetivo principal de esta iniciativa es sensibilizar a las nuevas generaciones sobre la importancia de adoptar prácticas de transporte sostenible en entornos urbanos. Esta acción se enmarca dentro de un proyecto más amplio de divulgación de la Mancomunitat Erasmus+, en consonancia con las nuevas directrices educativas que incluyen la enseñanza de contenidos relacionados con la movilidad desde las etapas primarias de educación. Se busca así prevenir y abordar a largo plazo los problemas asociados con la movilidad insostenible. Unas expectativas que serán difíciles de superar en la siguiente jornada, que se llevará a cabo el martes 20 de febrero y dará continuidad a la iniciativa pionera con la que l'Horta Sud recibe la oportunidad de mejorar su día a día a través de una movilidad más sostenible y acorde con los nuevos valores medioambientales. Al finalizar las sesiones, se realizará una evaluación para determinar la continuidad de la iniciativa en futuras ediciones, con la posibilidad de ampliar su alcance a otros cursos escolares en los próximos años. Colaboran Itera, UPV, Nunsys, V2 Charge, Next Electric Motors e Itene.
